intro: Cinchona brasiliensis, commonly known as the Peruvian bark, is a species of tree native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its dark green, lance-shaped leaves and yellow flowers. The plant is most notable for its bark, which contains alkaloids such as quinine, historically used to treat malaria. Cinchona brasiliensis typically grows in humid, shaded environments at high altitudes. Its cultivation has played a significant role in the global pharmaceutical industry.
